NOTES ON AIRPORT
Tuesday, Sept. 14, 1926.
Called on Mr. Shaw,
South San Francisco Land and Improve-
ment Company, Merchants Exchange Building.
Suggested that the limit to be paid by the City for the
100 acres involved in site No. 2 would be
$260,000.00, provided that
the land be brought to an elevation of plus 10 feet by the present
owner; that in addition, the land Company
would have to include
a right of way for a spur track from the Belt Railroad into the
proposed aeroplane site.
Mr. Shaw stated that if we submitted the offer it would
be forwarded to his company, but that he would not recommend its
acceptance.
Mr.
Shaw's
price on
the above
mentioned above is $340,000.00 for
site
as per the
conditions
an area
of approximately 100
acres.
Tuesday,
Sept.

1926.
Called on Mr. Medina,
Mr. Howard Sr. and Mr. Howard Jr.,
Bank of California, in re site No. 1.
They agreed to sell to the City all land that we wish
of the
present transmission line and including the land on
both sides of the Bay Shore Boulevard, with the exception of two
easements for
road purposes at the northerly and southerly
boundaries,
these easements to be used for road purposes only.
Would deliver
the
same
subject to confirmation on the part of
Mrs.
Taylor for $2,000.00 per acre.
stated to them that the price should be between $750.00
and $1,000.00 per acre, and requested
them to submit this proposi-
tion to
their principals.
Wednesday morning
and would give me an answer by the 2th ot the
Howard Sr. said that he would leave
21st of

NOTES ON AIRPORT
Friday, Sept. 17, 1926.
request
of the Chamber of Commerce and suggested
by the
Supervisors attending the luncheon to Assistant Secretary
of the Navy Warner,
I met Mr.
Warner and the officers of the
Twelfth Naval Division at Harrison and Spear Streets at 2:30 o'clock.
We left about 3:00 o'clock and
visited the South San Francisco site
Millbrae site.
Did not visit the San Mateo
site,
as it was not
suitable for hydroplanes.
Returned to San Francisco
at 4:45 o'clock.
The Assistant Secretary expressed the opinion that the
site at South San Francisco was not admirably adapted for hydro-
mans to the drop she would pre
as the hydroplane would probably have to taxi
at some three
Depth of water
is needed for
hydroplanes,
according to the Assistant Secretary,
in order to enable
deliver supplies direct to the hydroplanes.
We also visited the Millbrae site and the Assistant
Secretary
said that it appeared to him that this was a much better
Not being familiar with the direction of the winds at all
times he could not state whether it was ideal or not.
He also asked
concerning drainage on both sites and whether during
the winter
season the land would be waterlogged.
He also made the statement
if it were a question of securing a field not suitable for
hydroplanes but absolutely clear of fog, that he would select that
field rather than take a field suitable for hydroplanes that had
fog at times.
Mr.
Guersey of the Chamber of Commerce accompanied the
party;
also Rear-Admiral Thomas Washington,
Commandant of the District,
of the Supply Corps,

properties.sfomuseum:description: Transcript of meeting minutes, City and County of San Francisco, concerning allocation of site south of San Francisco for temporary airport;a. document titled “Notes on Airport,” dated September 14, 1926;b. document titled “Notes on Airport,” dated September 17, 1926.
